overview: This subject provides an introduction to the theory, experimental design and practice of techniques used in molecular biology and genetic analysis. Students work collaboratively to perform a series of laboratory-based practicals to explore fundamental principles in genetics and molecular genetic analysis of microorganisms and higher organisms. A key component of this subject is the development of analytical skills associated with the interpretation of genetic data and the communication of results.
ilo: describe the theoretical basis of techniques used in molecular biology and genetic analysis;
perform experiments to investigate gene function, test gene interactions and characterise gene expression;
analyse and interpret experimental data and apply appropriate statistical analyses to complex datasets
collate and present data in a scientific format; and
evaluate and solve molecular and genetics-based problems
generic_skills: Problem-solving skills: ability to work in small groups or individually to solve problems
Analytical skills: capacity to follow detailed experimental protocols to generate, collect and analyze experimental data
Communication skills: ability to ccommunicate experimental outcomes in a clear, concise and accurate manner
Collaborative skills: capacity to work in small groups to perform experiments, solve problems and communicate research findings
Time management skills: ability to plan effective work schedules to accomplish laboratory tasks and to meet deadlines.

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Participation in pre-workshop preparation by submitting multiple choice/short answer quiz responses (x10), 10 minutes per quiz, weekly throughout semester
Three individual written tasks related to practical material due in week 4, 8 and 12 (10% each)
Group Assignment involving the preparation of a poster
An individual in-class or online multiple-choice/short-answer test

date_times.contact_hours: 24 hours of workshops (1 x two hour workshop per week); 36 hours of practical classes (1 x three hour practical class per week); 24 hours of online work (two hours per week) including preparation for workshops, practical classes, independent learning tasks and non-assessed quizzes.
